title: Blue Origin may not send humans to space until 2020 - postponing goal for second time in two years
text:
Jeff Bezo's aerospace upstart, Blue Origin, may still be a ways off from sending humans to space according to new updates from the company.

In a press event this week, the company said that while it still hopes to launch humans into space via its New Shepard rocket before the end of the year, previously planned test flights and dwindling time could push the goal back another year.

The company had previously planned to bring humans into space with the rocket by 2018, but has pushed that goal back two times since then.

Blue Origin is coming close to amending its projections on when it might be able to bring passengers to space aboard its reusable New Shepard rocket (File photo)

SpaceX CEO Bob Smith tells CNBC that the postponements aren't a reflection on the rocket's viability.

'It’s really the robustness of our entire system. It’s not one individual thing that’s driving [these delays],' said Smith according to CNBC.

'It’s us being cautious and thorough with the total systems we need to verify.'

On Tuesday, the company filed an application with the FCC for 'Flight #12 of the New Shepard space launch booster and capsule,' for which a window doesn't open until November.

New Shepard, a reusable rocket akin to those being tested and designed by Elon Musk's SpaceX, is being designed as a craft for space tourism and plans to bring up to six passengers to the edge of space.

There, the passengers would float for 10 minutes in zero gravity and return to Earth.

Despite delays, Bezos' Blue Origin is among the favorites in an upcoming NASA mission to land humans back on the moon in 2024 -- a feat that would mark the first time humans had stepped foot on the lunar surface in almost 50 years.

New Shepard has launched nearly a dozen times successfully and is making its case to be the first craft capable of bringing domestic passengers to space (File photo)

Already, Blue Origin has received multiple contracts from NASA to study and design prototypes for landers, propulsion systems, and more last month, some of which would help to enable the use of reusable landers and space mining - a growing fixation by NASA.

Through NASA's Innovative Advanced Concepts (NIAC) program, the agency said it will begin to explore the feasibility of robotic rovers and mining technology that could make space mining a reality.

To do so, it has green-lit two mission concepts this year.

NASA's next moon mission, Artemis, also plans to establish a permanent base on the moon's surface from which mining operations could originate.
